Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Reducing Manufacturing Cost for the Energy Industry through Predictive Process Modeling

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) award supports fundamental research on the link between machining dynamics and process performance. Research results can lead to machining high-quality parts under conditions that are traditionally avoided because they are considered unstable. This new approach can provide increased material removal rates and, consequently, reduced machining times, while simultaneously producing high quality parts. Collaboration with a partner from the energy industry will help ensure the technology transfer to this and other manufacturing industries. The award also supports two education outreach efforts: (1) Project Engineering for Me, one-day events for middle school girls in Charlotte-Mecklenburg schools, that includes a discussion of engineering careers, a team competition, group brainstorming to discuss how engineers can impact society, and assessment through questionnaires; and (2) the Pigskin Professor Advanced Manufacturing video series that describes advanced manufacturing concepts in simple language.

The research focus is period-n bifurcations (i.e., a special category of chatter, or self-excited vibration) in low radial immersion milling. The research objective is to establish relationships: (1) between the period-n behavior (which describes the number of periods, n, between repetitions of the vibration state) and milling parameters (spindle speed, axial and radial depths of cut, and feed per tooth); (2) between the period-n behavior and geometric accuracy of machined parts; and (3) between the period-n behavior and surface roughness of machined parts. The approach to achieve the objective is to derive a comprehensive time domain model by solving a set of second order delay differential equations that describe the milling process. This time domain model will be used to predict these relationships. In addition, the time domain model will be used to select experimental conditions that exhibit period-n bifurcations. Machining experiments will then be conducted under these conditions using aluminum, steel, and nickel alloys. For each machining experiment, the period-n behavior will be measured by a laser vibrometer, part accuracy will be measured using coordinate metrology, and surface roughness will be measured by coherence scanning interferometry. The measurement data will then be compared with the model predictions, including period-n behavior, part accuracy, and surface roughness.

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
This GOALI, or Grant Opportunities for Academic Liaison with Industry, research project represents a collaboration between the University of Tennessee, Knoxville and GE to study milling, a manufacturing process when material is removed by a rotating cutting tool with sharp edges to reveal the desired part geometry and surface finish. The starting material may be a metal plate, casting, forging, or additively manufactured preform. The research objective was to gain fundamental new knowledge about a special category of chatter, or self-excited vibration, in low radial immersion milling referred to as period-n bifurcations. Given this physics-based milling understanding, the deterministic physics-based modeling approach was then extended to a probabilistic approach for predicting the milling stability. The probabilistic approach applied a Bayesian machine learning framework, where the numerical model was used within a Monte Carlo simulation to propagate input uncertainties into uncertainties in the stability boundary. This uncertain stability boundary was then used as the prior for the Bayesian analysis. Once the prior was established using the physics-based model, experiments were performed to update the stability boundary.

The intellectual merit includes new knowledge about: the order of the period-n bifurcation behavior, which describes the number of periods, n, between repetitions of the vibration state, as a function of the milling parameters (spindle speed, axial and radial depths of cut, and feed per tooth); the relationship between the period-n behavior and geometric part accuracy; the relationship between the period-n behavior and surface finish; and machine learning modeling for milling stability. The knowledge gap that was addressed in this research was the relationship between part quality (accuracy and finish) and the process dynamics while machining under period-n bifurcation conditions. The innovation was choosing to machine in an unstable state (chatter), which is traditionally avoided because low quality parts are produced.

The broader impacts of this research are the opportunity to reduce the cost and energy consumption in machining through improved process understanding and modeling, including machine learning. Without the new understanding gained by this research, cost savings are lost because the new approach enables increased material removal rates and, consequently, reduced machining times while at the same time producing acceptable parts. This is important not only for the GOALI partner, GE, but also for any US or global manufacturer that uses subtractive machining to produce discrete parts.

Modified by: Tony L Schmitz
